job_title: Systems Administrator in Lees Summit, MO
pros: Great for a first time IT job. Loved interacting with the residents.
cons:
Pay is not competitive for the job titles or responsibilities. JKV does not pay for training or education for the IT department. Managers do not support working from home (even during a pandemic) due to the inability to micromanage even though most tasks could be done from home and a tech could plan accordingly for things that cannot. There was also overt favoritism between management and staff.

The main building is dated with cracked windows in some offices and pink or green carpeting from the 60s/70s in others.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Lees Summit, MO
pros: Loved the people I worked with.  I worked on different units within the care center.  Great managers on 300 & 400 unit. No matter your position, what you do impacts the residents. Could be better in both areas, but adequate pay and benefits.  I think management really cares, but is overwhelmed. Everyone very friendly and helpful from the HR folks, Staffing, other nursing staff, dietary staff, etc
cons: Often times the workload is more than any average person can handle. I know staffing nurses and aides is tough these days and doesn't help, but even when staffing is really good it's too much.

review_title: The residents are wonderful, management not so much
job_title: Server in Lees Summit, MO
pros: The residents are incredible, they become like family. Things are very consistent here, there's never  any big changes. There is a wonderful feeling of community between staff and residents.
cons: There is a high turnover rate. The benefits are expensive and not worth it in my opinion. If you're full time and dont make 32 hrs a week, they will destroy your PTO...even if your managers are the ones who cut your hours. You do get a lot of it though. The pay could always be better. Not a forever job. I've always had issues with scheduling.

job_title: in Kansas City, MO
pros: The cons far outweigh any pros.
cons: Their minds are already made up about you.  They write you up and expect you to sign without including you in the investigation, believing that whatever was said about you is true.  Old complaints, even unfounded, are never removed from your file.  What you say falls on deaf ears.

job_title: Administrative Assistant PRN in Lees Summit, MO
pros: There are some really hard working people there.  On the admin side I found most were very capable and willing to help out between departments and within.  A lot of great nurses there who genuinely care about the residents.  I would work there again.
cons: As PRN nights and weekends are mandatory.  But the place runs 24 hours, so what can I say?  Working staffing could be difficult for a PRN, some nurses like to push newbies around.

review_title: Incompetence Gets Rewarded Within Home Health DepartmentHome Health
job_title: Marketing Liaison in Kansas City, MO
pros: Flexibility of role. Hospice Department runs like a well oiled machine.
cons: Unqualified home Health leadership allowed to retaliate at will. Staff in the field are unable to voice opinions/concerns as it falls on deaf ears.  Revolving door with care staff (RNs) goes without anyone being held accountable. HR is only there to protect those in leadership and does not do right by any employee expressing patient safety or care issues.

review_title: CNA at a morally bankrupt organization
job_title: CNA in Lees Summit, MO
pros: The residents and a few co workers from different units and departments.
cons:
This is the most disgustingly, morally corrupt place I've ever encountered! 
I reported abuse and neglect, I was made to write a statement and sign it with the guarantee of it being private. Nope!  The supervisor of the unit (and possibly HR) took it to the accused and let her read the accusations and told her the names of the people who accused her. (There were several employees dealing with this). 
There was backlash to us all, which was reported, and ignored and covered up by HR and the supervisor. Yet the abuse and neglect of the residents continues.. months later! 
There was an "investigation," yet when you tell someone the complaints and that they're being investigated they can cover it up when they need to. We've told the unit supervisor "this abuse or neglect is happening right now go check it out" and she just throws her hands up like there's nothing she can do about it. 
Let me tell you, the things that happen here to residents and employees are lawsuit worthy!

HR will lie to your face; there's favoritism and absolutely no regard for the well being of the residents. There's a reason they're constantly hiring and offering incentives... 
The same abuse and neglect is continuing, yet now people are too scared to report it anymore. This whole organization should be under investigation. 
Plus this has been going on for years... Ive talked to numerous former employees with similar horror stories.  Its so sad for the residents and the employees who care about them. These residents deserve so much better.
